awd_titl_txt: TWC: Medium: Collaborative: Towards a Binary-Centric Framework for Cyber Forensics in Enterprise Environments
awd_abstract_narration:
Emerging attacks such as Advanced Persistent Threats pose significant threat to cyberspace. These attacks are often stealthy, low-and-slow, and disguised via deceptive campaigns. This research focuses on the forensics of cyber attacks targeting enterprise environments, with the goals of (1) understanding an attack's intent, strategy, steps, and targets, (2) collecting digital evidence for legal proceedings, (3) revealing hidden attack behaviors to prevent or minimize damage.

To achieve these goals, an integrated framework is being developed which covers three key aspects - temporal, spatial, and malware-behavioral forensics. All three aspects face the common challenge of analyzing binary executables. More specifically, temporal forensics requires finer-grain program logging for identifying attack provenance and ramifications. The solution is to partition a binary program's execution and data for high-accuracy causal analysis. Malware forensics involves revealing malware behaviors that are multi-stage, condition-guarded, and environment-specific. The solution is a new binary analysis approach that force-executes an unknown binary without input or environment setup and exposes the malware's behavior along the execution paths forced into. Temporal forensics requires understanding unknown file formats and in-memory data structure contents. The solution is to identify and reuse the file parsing/generation and data structure rendering logic in the corresponding binary programs.

This research will advance the state-of-the-art in cyber forensics, a critical need as our nation and society become increasingly dependent on cyberinfrastructures. It will help train next-generation cybersecurity experts by exposing students to real case investigations. Under-represented students are being involved in research activities and cyber forensics exercises.

por.por_cntn:
This project has resulted in the development of an integrated framework for temporal, spatial, and behavioral forensics of advanced cyber attacks against enterprises. The research team has addressed challenges and limitations of existing forensics techniques and introduced new capabilities based on in-depth analysis of executable computer code.

In temporal forensics, this project has produced a spectrum of methods and tools to generate, protect, and analyze audit logs and records from multiple vantage points of an enterprise network. The goal is to identify "needles in a haystack" (i.e., attack-related log entries in the entire log data set) and then "connect the dots" to correlate and sequence attack actions and impacts to reconstruct an end-to-end attack story from attack onset to aftermath. These methods overcome long-existing problems in audit log analytics by accurately capturing the causal relations between log entries with low overhead in both time and space dimensions.

In malware forensics, this project has addressed the limitations of existing executable computer program analysis methods, such as static, dynamic, and symbolic analysis, in the face of sophisticated malware with multi-stage, condition-guarded, and environment-specific payloads. The team's solution is able to force-execute a totally unknown binary program without any input or environment setup. When encountering a conditional branch in the program, all branches will be explored by force-setting different conditional outcomes, hence fully exposing the malware's behaviors along those execution paths.

In spatial forensics, this project has generated a suite of powerful tools for uncovering semantic data of forensic value from images of persistent (e.g., hard disk) and volatile (e.g., RAM) computer memory. The semantic data that can be recovered include images, documents, contact information, chat history, and mobile app activities. Such tools are enabled by extracting a program?s own data rendering and interpretation functions, and then invoking such functions on a subject memory image. As a result, the in-memory content can be recovered and rendered in a human-understandable form.  

Results from this project have been published at top cybersecurity conferences, including the ACM Conference on Computer and Communications Security (CCS), USENIX Security Symposium (USENIX Security), and Network and Distributed System Security Symposium (NDSS). The research team received a number of awards from these conferences, including the Best Student Paper Award from USENIX Security'14, Best Paper Award from CCS'15, and Distinguished Paper Award from NDSS'16.

This project has generated significant broader impacts: prototypes and techniques from this project have been demonstrated and transferred to the following companies and organizations, including Cisco, Google, Intelligent Automation, Northrop Grumman, SRI International, and Sandia National Laboratories. In 2014, the team's malware forensics tool discovered new malicious payloads of an Advanced Persistent Threat (APT) attack, missed by a published report (by SANS Institute) on the same attack. In 2015, the team's malware forensics techniques helped Apple detect, confirm, and remove hundreds of privacy-violating apps from its App Store. Four PhD students and two MS students have graduated from this project. Three of the PhD graduates are currently assistant professors at Georgia Tech, Rutgers University, and University of Virginia, respectively.

A Cyber Forensics Summer School was offered to high school teachers at the University of New Orleans in 2015. In collaboration with Sandia National Labs, a two-day cyber forensics training camp (TracerFIRE) is now offered to undergraduate students every semester at Purdue University.
